answers.answer: the choice one makes.
the next best thing given up when one makes a decision.
the price of a product one buys.
the profit a firm earns beyond its production costs.
the price of the resources needed to make a product.

hotspots.hotspot: The financial costs of college include tuition, books, and fees. An additional cost involves your time. Depending on the college degree you want, you could spend two to eight years going to college.

The opportunity costs of college include the other things you could do with the money, such as buying a house or a nice car, AND the other things you could do with your time. You could work full-time for the years that you go to college.
The benefits from going to college include the increased yearly income resulting from that education and having the qualifications to do the work you desire.

multiple.question:
Why is opportunity cost important in economic
decision-making?

answers.answer: It increases the profit earned by corporations.
It is the sum of all of the costs of production for a firm.
It requires us to consider the alternative uses of our time and resources.
It is the cost of producing one more unit of output, a number firms use to determine their profit-maximizing output.
It requires us to analyze the money we spend on goods and services.

multiple.question: Robert Frost's poem "The Road Not Taken" can be used to illustrate the economic concept of

answers.answer: supply and demand.
profit maximization.
externalities.
opportunity cost.
public goods.

figure.header: The Road Not Taken
figure.text:
Two roads diverged in a yellow wood,
And sorry I could not travel both
And be one traveler, long I stood. . . .
••••••••••••••••••••
Two roads diverged in a wood, and I–
I took the one less traveled by,
And that has made all the difference.

—"The Road Not Taken" by Robert Frost

multiple.question: If you decided to buy a doughnut on your way to school, which of the following would best represent the opportunity cost of your decision to buy the doughnut?

answers.answer: The after-school snack you could have bought with the same money
Your college education
Three hours you could have spent studying for a test
The time you worked to earn the money to pay for the doughnut
The doughnut you bought

multiple.question: Why must entrepreneurs consider opportunity cost when deciding whether to open a business?

answers.answer: Opportunity costs are generally higher than production costs.
Opportunity costs add to the profit of the company.
Entrepreneurs must ensure that the costs outweigh the benefits of the project.
Consumers will not buy the product if the company is not profitable.
Entrepreneurs are giving up the ability to use their time and money for another project.

multiple.question: Which of these common sayings does NOT illustrate a choice involving an opportunity cost?

answers.answer: "There is no such thing as a free lunch."
"You can't have your cake and eat it, too."
"I can have the best of both worlds."
"I'm on the horns of a dilemma."
"Choosing the lesser of two evils."

multiple.question: Even a product that is supposedly "free" to consumers involves an opportunity cost because

answers.answer: the firm that produced the product always increases its profit from such "giveaways."
the resources used to make the product could have been used to make other things.
"free" products are generally produced at a higher cost than other products.
consumers will be less likely to buy products from that producer in the future.
the product would have been thrown away if it hadn't been given to consumers.
